Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Modulation of the Inflammatory Response for Accelerated Tissue Vascularization and Bone Regeneration

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1631439-Jabbarzadeh

There is a profound need for bone regeneration strategies due to trauma and various musculoskeletal diseases. Current approaches to treat bone defects are associated with limitations such as shortage of donors and risk of disease transmission. Strategies built on tissue engineering offer alternative avenues to repair and regenerate bone tissue. The transfer of tissue engineering methodology from the lab to the clinic is limited by the inadequate vascular growth and host inflammatory response. This study establishes the proof of principle for the use of resveratrol, a natural compound found in berries and grapes, to harness the potential of immune cells to drive blood vessel growth. Through a systematic investigation of the effects of resveratrol on the interactions between immune cells and stem cells, this research will pave the way for a solution to the major clinical problem of bone regeneration. Successful completion of this work will impact a wide range of patients suffering from debilitating musculoskeletal conditions. The educational goals of this proposal are tightly linked to the scientific aims. The educational objectives of this proposal are to integrate research findings into a new course curriculum, facilitate the dissemination of results to both the scientific community and public, and promote participation of students from underrepresented groups in the field of biomedical engineering.

This project addresses the profound need for bone regeneration strategies due to trauma and various musculoskeletal diseases. Current approaches to treat bone defects include autografts and allografts that are associated with limitations such as shortage of donors and risk of disease transmission. Strategies built on tissue engineering offer alternative approaches to repair and regenerate tissues. The transfer of tissue engineering methodology from the lab to the clinic is limited by the failure to adequately vascularize scaffolds following implantation. The goal of this project is to promote the neogenesis of bone and supporting vasculature in a synchronized manner similar to the physiological process of bone growth during maturation. The project is transformative in nature in that contrary to conventional methods, instead of trying to counteract inflammation, the proposed approach establishes the proof of principle for the use of resveratrol, a natural polyphenol, to regulate immune cell behavior and use their secreted signaling molecules to drive vasculogenesis and bone formation. The approach involves the use of (i) a resveratrol, a natural polyphenol found commonly in grapes and berries, (ii) a biomimetic scaffold with native bone extracellular matrix protein components, and (iii) mesenchymal stem cells. Rapid perfusion throughout an implanted scaffold is a critical issue for engineering the repair of a wide variety of tissues in addition to bone. The study delineate the potential of resveratrol as a potent physiological cue to control inflammatory response with many applications beyond the fields of tissue engineering and regenerative medicine (e.g. tumor inflammation). The educational goals include development of an elective course on principles of stem cells engineering and promoting participation of students from underrepresented groups in the field of biomedical engineering.

Institution.Name: University of South Carolina at Columbia

Performance_Institution.Name: University of South Carolina at Columbia

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
OVERVIEW

Inflammation is the process by which the body protects itself from intruders, and if left uncontrolled, potentially interferes with the integration of implanted biomaterials. It is a protective mechanism involving various cell types (neutrophils, basophils, Mast cells, T-cells, B-cells, monocytes, and macrophages), cytokines, and chemokines that help to restore tissue homeostasis. The complicated interplay of cells and cytokines at the interface of an implanted biomaterial must be deconstructed in order to properly design an approach to harness inflammation and promote wound healing. The major objective of this study was to determine the effects of resveratrol (RSV) in the presence of nicotinamide (NAM) on macrophage phenotype, and explore methods to boosts its anti-inflammatory potential. Specifically, we sought to understand the signaling mechanisms by which resveratrol modulates macrophage phenotype plasticity from M1 (pro-inflammatory) to M2 (pro-healing). This study paves the way toward harnessing the inflammatory response to biomaterials and increase the likelihood of successful integration and graft success based on the use of a single natural dietary molecule.

INTELLECTUAL MERIT

The proposed study established a fundamental understanding of the interlinkage between angiogenesis and inflammation. In addition, this study delineated the potential of resveratrol as a potent physiological cue to control inflammatory response with many applications beyond the fields of tissue engineering and regenerative medicine (e.g. tumor inflammation). The data obtained in this study provide information on baseline cytokine profile of LPS induce M1 macrophages, and the anti-inflammatory effects of NAM and RSV in this system. We evaluated the effect of resveratrol and nicotinamide on the production of inflammatory mediators (IL-6, TNF-α, IL-10, MRC-1, and VEGF) on LPS-IFN-γ induced macrophages (M1 macrophages). Our data demonstrated the suppression of IL-6 and TNF-α levels at different time points (2, and 5 days) after RSV and NAM treated M1 macrophages. The results suggest that a combination of resveratrol with nicotinamide would trigger the conversion of nicotinamide into NAD+ through the salvage pathway and would result in a favorable immune response for a longer period of time. PARP-1 was activated in M1 macrophages in the presence of RSV, NAM, or RSV+NAM. These findings suggested that the anti-inflammatory effect of RSV and NAM is independent of the action of sirtuins. We demonstrated that the anti-inflammatory effect of NAM and RSV critically rely on their ability to activate Poly [ADP-ribose] polymerase 1 (PARP-1) for the first time. Our work further delineates the potential of pharmacologically active natural compounds to modulate inflammation with broad applicability in regenerative medicine and drug discovery. Results from the funded research have been published within three manuscripts in peer-reviewed journal of high impact factor, including Current Pharmaceutical Design, Molecules, and American Journal of Cancer Research. A final manuscript is currently in pipeline to be submitted in November.

BROADER IMPACTS

Research on stem cells has initiated much of debates and public interests. By expanding capabilities in control of stem cell biological functions, we will enable the development of novel therapeutic avenues to treat diseases and improve the lives of patients suffering from debilitating medical conditions. The proposed research will facilitate this goal by providing an understanding of the underlying physiological mechanisms that contribute to stem cell function and differentiation. This insight will provide a rational basis for designing stem cell technologies and facilitate their use in regenerative medicine.

Results of the proposed research project were integrated into an elective course on the application of stem cells at the undergraduate level in Biomedical Engineering Program. This course provided a comprehensive overview of stem cell biology and focuses on the biology of stem cells and their role in health and disease with an emphasis on regenerative medicine. Lectures covered embryonic and fetal and adult stem cells in blood, liver brain, and bone marrow. The class has a laboratory component in which students culture stem cells, transplant cells in tissue engineering scaffolds and monitor the differentiation of stem cells. Considering that the most common learning style among engineering students is a visual and sensing, inductive, and active one, the PI expect that these tools can truly make a difference in student learning outcomes and course perception.

The educational goals of this proposal were tightly linked to the scientific concepts. The PI was actively involved in educational initiatives to recruit undergraduate students into his research group. The project activities entailed an interdisciplinary approach of bioengineering, which significantly broadened the scientific and technical knowledge of the students involved.

 


Last Modified: 10/12/2017
Modified by: Ehsan Jabbarzadeh
